page.title: 04STREET END FORGE AND AREA
page.content: The forge is a timber framed building with some flint stone walls and a roof of Kent Peg Tiles. Although it has not been used for horse-shoeing since 1962 there is evidence that it was in existence before 1787. One man still works here, carrying out repairs and making items in wrought iron and steel. Behind the forge is a builders' yard and carpenters' shop, used in the early 19th century by the wheelwright. Nearby is a coin operated telephone box, a seat and bus stop with glass- framed timetable. Operated by the East Kent Bus Company, a limited service runs to Canterbury, Folkestone, Hythe or Waltham. At the same junction is a stone sign marking a Bridleway. These stones are erected by the Highways Authorities and local interested Groups to mark the Public Rights of Way.
